Cost-Effective Federated Learning Design

Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a distributed learning paradigm that enables a large number of devices to collaboratively learn a model without sharing their raw data. Despite its practical efficiency and effectiveness, the iterative on-device learning process incurs a considerable cost in terms of learning time and energy consumption, which depends crucially on the number of selected clients and the number of local iterations in each training round. In this paper, we analyze how to design adaptive FL that optimally chooses these essential control variables to minimize the total cost while ensuring convergence. Theoretically, we analytically establish the relationship between the total cost and the control variables with the convergence upper bound. To efficiently solve the cost minimization problem, we develop a low-cost sampling-based algorithm to learn the convergence related unknown parameters. We derive important solution properties that effectively identify the design principles for different metric preferences. Practically, we evaluate our theoretical results both in a simulated environment and on a hardware prototype. Experimental evidence verifies our derived properties and demonstrates that our proposed solution achieves near-optimal performance for various datasets, different machine learning models, and heterogeneous system settings.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) has recently emerged as an attractive distributed learning paradigm, which enables many clients111Depending on the type of clients, FL can be categorized into cross-device FL and cross-silo FL (clients are companies or organizations, etc.) [1]. This paper focuses on the former and we use â€œdeviceâ€ and â€œclientâ€ interchangeably. to collaboratively train a model under the coordination of a central server, while keeping the training data decentralized and private[2, 3, 1, 4, 5, 6]. In FL settings, the training data are generally massively distributed over a large number of devices, and the communication between the server and clients are typically operated at lower rates compared to datacenter settings. These unique features necessitate FL algorithms that perform multiple local iterations in parallel on a fraction of randomly sampled clients and then aggregate the resulting model update via the central server periodically [2]. FL has demonstrated empirical success and theoretical convergence guarantees in various heterogeneous settings, e.g., unbalanced and non-i.i.d. data distribution [7, 8, 2, 9, 10, 11].

Because model training and information transmission for on-device FL can be both time and energy consuming, it is necessary and important to analyze the cost that is incurred for completing a given FL task. In general, the cost of FL includes multiple components such as learning time and energy consumption [12]. The importance of different cost components depends on the characteristics of FL systems and applications. For example, in a solar-based sensor network, energy consumption is the major concern for the sensors to participate in FL tasks, whereas in a multi-agent search-and-rescue task where the goal is to collaboratively learn an unknown map, achieving timely result would be the first priority. Therefore, a cost-effective FL design needs to jointly optimize various cost components (e.g., learning time and energy consumption) for different preferences.

A way of optimizing the cost is to adapt control variables in the FL process to achieve a properly defined objective. For example, some existing works have considered the adaptation of communication interval (i.e., the number of local iterations between two global aggregation rounds) for communication-efficient FL with convergence guarantees [13, 14]. However, a limitation in these works is that they only adapt a single control variable (i.e., communication interval) in the FL process and ignore other essential aspects, such as the number of participating clients in each round, which can have a significant impact on the energy consumption.

In this paper, we consider a multivariate control problem for cost-efficient FL with convergence guarantees. To minimize the expected cost, we develop an algorithm that adapts various control variables in the FL process to achieve our goal. Compared to the univariate setting in existing works, our problem is much more challenging due to the following reasons: 1)Â The choices of control variables are tightly coupled. 2)Â The relationship between the control variables and the learning convergence rate has only been captured by an upper bound with unknown coefficients in the literature. 3) Our cost objective includes multiple components (e.g., time and energy) which can have different importance depending on the system and application scenario, whereas existing works often consider a single optimization objective such as minimizing the communication overhead.

As illustrated in Fig.Â 1, we consider the number of participating clients (Kğ¾{K}) and the number of local iterations (Eğ¸{E}) in each FL round as our control variables. A similar methodology can be applied to analyze problems with other control variables as well. We analyze, for the first time, how to design adaptive FL that optimally chooses Kğ¾K and Eğ¸E to minimize the total cost while ensuring convergence. Our main contributions are as follows:

  • â€¢

    Optimization Algorithm: We establish the analytical relationship between the total cost, control variables, and convergence upper bound for strongly convex objective functions, based on which an optimization problem for total cost minimization is formulated and analyzed. We propose a sampling-based algorithm to learn the unknown parameters in the convergence bound with marginal estimation overhead. We show that our optimization problem is biconvex with respect to Kğ¾K and Eğ¸E, and develop efficient ways to solve it based on closed-form expressions.

  • â€¢

    Theoretical Properties: We theoretically obtain important properties that effectively identify the design principles for different optimization goals. Notably, the choice of Kğ¾K leads to an interesting trade-off between learning time reduction and energy saving, with a large Kğ¾K favoring the former while a small Kğ¾K benefiting the later. Nevertheless, we show that a relatively low device participation rate does not severely slow down the learning. For the choice of Eğ¸E, we show that neither a too small or too large Eğ¸E is good for cost-effectiveness. The optimal value of Eğ¸E also depends on the relationship between computation and communication costs.

  • â€¢

    Simulation and Experimentation: We evaluate our theoretical results with real datasets, both in a simulated environment and on a hardware prototype with 202020 Raspberry Pi devices. Experimental results verify our design principles and derived properties of Kğ¾K and Eğ¸E. They also demonstrate that our proposed optimization algorithm provides near-optimal solution for both real and synthetic datasets with non-i.i.d. data distributions. Particularly, we highlight that our approach works well with both convex non-convex machine learning models empirically.

II Related Work

FL was first proposed in [2], which demonstrated FLâ€™s effectiveness of collaboratively learning a model without collecting usersâ€™ data. Compared to distributed learning in data centers, FL needs to address several unique challenges, including non-i.i.d. and unbalanced data, limited communication bandwidth, and limited device availability (partial participation) [1, 5]. It was suggested that FL algorithms should operate synchronously due to its composability with other techniques such as secure aggregation protocols [15], differential privacy [16], and model compression [17]. Hence, we consider synchronous FL in this paper with all the aforementioned characteristics.

The de facto FL algorithm is federated averaging (FedAvg), which performs multiple local iterations in parallel on a subset of devices in each round. A system-level FL framework was presented in [8], which demonstrates the empirical success of FedAvg in mobile devices using TensorFlow [18]. Recently, a convergence bound of FedAvg was established in [11]. Other related distributed optimization algorithms are mostly for i.i.d. datasets [19, 20, 21] and full client participation [22, 9, 23], which do not capture the essence of on-device FL. Some extensions of FedAvg considered aspects such as adding a proximal termÂ [10] and using accelerated gradient descent methodsÂ [24]. These works did not consider optimization for cost/resource efficiency.

Literature in FL cost optimization mainly focused on learning time and on-device energy consumption. The optimization of learning time was studied in [25, 26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 31, 32], and joint optimization for learning time and energy consumption was considered in [33, 34, 35]. These works considered cost-aware client scheduling [25, 26, 27, 28], task offloading[36] and resource (e.g., transmission power, communication bandwidth, and CPU frequency) allocation [29, 30, 12, 33, 34, 35] for pre-specified (i.e., non-optimized) design parameters (Kğ¾K and Eğ¸E in our case) of the FL algorithm.

The optimization of a single design parameter Eğ¸E or the amount of information exchange, in general, was studied inÂ [13, 14, 12, 31, 37, 38], most of which assume full client participation and can be infeasible for large-scale on-device FL. A very recent work in [39] considered the optimization of both Eğ¸E and client selection for additive per-client costs. However, the cost related to learning time in our problem is non-additive on a per-client basis, because different clients perform local model updates in parallel. In addition, the convergence bound used inÂ [39] (and alsoÂ [12]) is for a primal-dual optimization algorithm, which is different from the commonly used FedAvg algorithm and does not reflect the impact of key FL characteristics such as partial client participation. The challenge in optimizing both Kğ¾K and Eğ¸E for cost minimization of FedAvg that takes into account all the aforementioned FL characteristics, which also distinguishes our work from the above, is the need to analytically connect the total cost with multiple control variables as well as with the convergence rate.

In addition, most existing work on FL are based on simulations, whereas we implement our algorithm in an actual hardware prototype with resource-constrained devices.

Roadmap: We present the system model and problem formulation in SectionÂ III. In SectionÂ IV, we analyze the cost minimization problem and present an algorithm to solve it. We provide theoretical analysis on the solution properties in SectionÂ V. Experimentation results are given in SectionÂ VI and the conclusion is presented in SectionÂ VII.

III System Model

We start by summarizing the basics of FL and its de facto algorithm FedAvg. Then, we present the cost model for a given FL task, and introduce our optimization problem formulation.

III-A Federated Learning

Consider a scenario with a large population of mobile clients that have data for training a machine learning model. Due to data privacy and bandwidth limitation concerns, it is not desirable for clients to disclose and send their raw data to a high-performance data center. FL is a decentralized learning framework that aims to resolve this problem. Mathematically, FL is the following distributed optimization problem:

While FL has demonstrated its effectiveness in many application scenarios, practitioners also need to take into account the cost that is incurred for completing a given task.

III-B Cost Analysis of Federated Learning

The total cost of FL, according to AlgorithmÂ 1, involves learning time and energy consumption, both of which are consumed during local computation (LineÂ 1) and global communication (LinesÂ 1 and 1) in each round. Before presenting each cost model, we first give the system assumptions.

System assumptions: Similar to existing works [2, 11, 10], we sample Kğ¾K clients in each round rğ‘Ÿr (i.e., K:=|ğ’¦(r)|assignğ¾superscriptğ’¦ğ‘ŸK:=\left|\mathcal{K}^{(r)}\right|) where the sampling is uniform (without replacement) out of all Nğ‘N clients. We assume the communication and computation cost for a particular device in each round is the same, but varies among devices due to system heterogeneity. We do not consider the cost for model aggregation in LineÂ 1, because it only needs to compute the average that is much less complex than local model updates.

III-B1 Time Cost

For general heterogeneous systems, each client can have different communication and computation capabilities (see Fig.Â 1). Let tksubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜t_{k} denote the per-round time for client kğ‘˜k to complete computation and communication. We have

III-C Problem Formulation

Considering the difference of the two cost metrics, the optimal solutions of Eğ¸E, Kğ¾K and Rğ‘…R generally do not achieve the common goal for minimizing both ttotsubscriptğ‘¡tott_{\textnormal{tot}} and etotsubscriptğ‘’tote_{\textnormal{tot}}. To strike the balance of learning time and energy consumption, we introduce a weight Î³âˆˆ[0,1]ğ›¾01\gamma\in\left[0,1\right] and optimize the balanced cost function in the following form:

Ctotâ€‹(K,E,R)=(1âˆ’Î³)â€‹ttotâ€‹(K,E,R)+Î³â€‹etotâ€‹(K,E,R),subscriptğ¶totğ¾ğ¸ğ‘…1ğ›¾subscriptğ‘¡totğ¾ğ¸ğ‘…ğ›¾subscriptğ‘’totğ¾ğ¸ğ‘…C_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)=\left(1-\gamma\right)t_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)+\gamma e_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R), (8)

where 1âˆ’Î³1ğ›¾1-\gamma and Î³ğ›¾\gamma can be interpreted as the normalized price of the two costs, i.e., how much monetary cost for one unit of time and one unit of energy, respectively. The value of Î³ğ›¾\gamma can be adjusted for different preferences. For example, we can set Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0 when all clients are plugged in and energy consumption is not a major concern, whereas Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1 when devices are solar-based sensors where saving the devicesâ€™ energy is the priority.

Our goal is to minimize the expected total cost while ensuring convergence, which translates into this problem:

P1:minE,K,Rğ”¼â€‹[Ctotâ€‹(E,K,R)]Â s.t.Â ğ”¼â€‹[Fâ€‹(ğ°R)]âˆ’Fâˆ—â‰¤Ïµ,K,E,Râˆˆâ„¤+,andâ€‹ 1â‰¤Kâ‰¤N.P1:subscriptğ¸ğ¾ğ‘…ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶totğ¸ğ¾ğ‘…Â s.t.Â ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘…superscriptğ¹italic-Ïµmissing-subexpressionformulae-sequenceğ¾ğ¸ğ‘…superscriptâ„¤and1ğ¾ğ‘\begin{array}[]{cl}\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\textbf{P1:}\quad\quad\min_{E,K,R}&\mathbb{E}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}(E,K,R)]\\ \quad\quad\text{ s.t. }&\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{w}_{R})]-F^{*}\leq\epsilon,\\ &K,E,R\in\mathbb{Z}^{+},\ \text{and}\ \ 1\leq K\leq N.\end{array} (9)

where ğ”¼â€‹[Fâ€‹(ğ°R)]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘…\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{w}_{R})] is the expected loss after Rğ‘…R rounds, Fâˆ—superscriptğ¹F^{*} is the (true and unknown) minimum value of Fğ¹F, and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is the desired precision. We note that the expectation in P1 is due to the randomness of SGD and client sampling in each round.

Solving P1 is challenging in two aspects. First, it is difficult to find an exact analytical expression to relate Eğ¸E, Kğ¾K and Rğ‘…R with Ctotsubscriptğ¶totC_{\textnormal{tot}}, especially due to the non-linear maximum function in ttotsubscriptğ‘¡tott_{\textnormal{tot}}. Second, it is generally impossible to obtain an exact analytical relationship to connect Eğ¸E, Kğ¾K and Rğ‘…R with the convergence constraint. In the following section, we propose an algorithm that approximately solves P1, which we later show with extensive experiments that the proposed solution can achieve a near-optimal performance of P1.

IV Cost-Effective Optimization Algorithm

This section shows how to approximately solve P1. We first formulate an alternative problem that includes an approximate analytical relationship between the expected cost ğ”¼â€‹[Ctot]ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶tot\mathbb{E}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}], the convergence constraint, and the control variables Eğ¸E, Kğ¾K and Rğ‘…R. Then, we show that this new optimization problem can be efficiently solved after estimating unknown parameters associated with the convergence bound, and we propose a sampling-based algorithm to learn these unknown parameters.

IV-A3 Analytical Relationship Between ğ”¼â€‹[Ctot]ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶tot\mathbb{E}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] and Convergence

Based on ğ”¼â€‹[etot]ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘’tot\mathbb{E}[e_{\textnormal{tot}}] in (10) and ğ”¼â€‹[ttot]ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘¡tot\mathbb{E}[{t_{\textnormal{tot}}}] in (12), the objective function ğ”¼â€‹[Ctot]ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶tot\mathbb{E}[{C_{\textnormal{tot}}}] in P1 can be expressed as

ğ”¼â€‹[Ctot]=((1âˆ’Î³)â€‹âˆ‘i=KNCiâˆ’1Kâˆ’1â€‹tiCNK+Î³â€‹Kâ€‹(epâ€‹E+em))â€‹R.ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶tot1ğ›¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ¾ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–1ğ¾1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘ğ¾ğ›¾ğ¾subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ¸subscriptğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘…\begin{array}[]{c}\mathbb{E}[{C_{\textnormal{tot}}}]\!=\!\left(\frac{\left(1-\!\gamma\right)\sum\nolimits_{i=K}^{N}{C_{i-1}^{K-1}t_{i}}}{C_{N}^{K}}\!+\!\gamma K\left(e_{p}E+e_{m}\right)\right)R.\end{array} (14)

To connect ğ”¼â€‹[Ctot]ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶tot\mathbb{E}[{C_{\textnormal{tot}}}] with the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-convergence constraint in (9), we utilize the convergence result [11]:

ğ”¼â€‹[Fâ€‹(ğ°R)]âˆ’Fâˆ—â‰¤1Eâ€‹Râ€‹(A0+B0â€‹(1+Nâˆ’KKâ€‹(Nâˆ’1))â€‹E2),ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ¹subscriptğ°ğ‘…superscriptğ¹1ğ¸ğ‘…subscriptğ´0subscriptğµ01ğ‘ğ¾ğ¾ğ‘1superscriptğ¸2\begin{array}[]{c}\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{w}_{R})]-F^{*}\leq\frac{1}{ER}\left(A_{0}+B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\right)E^{2}\right),\end{array} (15)

where A0subscriptğ´0A_{0} and B0subscriptğµ0B_{0} are loss function related constants characterizing the statistical heterogeneity of non-i.i.d. data. By letting the upper bound satisfy the convergence constraint,555We note that optimization using upper bound as an approximation has also been adopted in [13] and resource allocation based literature [12, 30, 35]. Although the convergence bound is valid for strongly convex problems, our experiments demonstrate that the proposed method also works well for non-convex learning problems empirically. and using (14) and LemmasÂ 1 and 2, we approximate P1 as

P2:â€‹minE,K,R((1âˆ’Î³)â€‹âˆ‘i=KNCiâˆ’1Kâˆ’1â€‹tiCNK+Î³â€‹Kâ€‹(epâ€‹E+em))â€‹RÂ s.t.Â 1Eâ€‹Râ€‹(A0+B0â€‹(1+Nâˆ’KKâ€‹(Nâˆ’1))â€‹E2)â‰¤ÏµK,E,Râˆˆâ„¤+,andâ€‹ 1â‰¤Kâ‰¤N.P2:subscriptğ¸ğ¾ğ‘…1ğ›¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ¾ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–1ğ¾1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘ğ¾ğ›¾ğ¾subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ¸subscriptğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘…Â s.t.Â 1ğ¸ğ‘…subscriptğ´0subscriptğµ01ğ‘ğ¾ğ¾ğ‘1superscriptğ¸2italic-Ïµmissing-subexpressionformulae-sequenceğ¾ğ¸ğ‘…superscriptâ„¤and1ğ¾ğ‘\begin{array}[]{cl}\!\!\!\!\!\!\textbf{P2:}\ \min_{E,K,R}&\!\!\!\left(\frac{\left(1-\!\gamma\right)\sum\nolimits_{i=K}^{N}{C_{i-1}^{K-1}t_{i}}}{C_{N}^{K}}\!+\!\gamma K\left(e_{p}E+e_{m}\right)\right)R\\ \quad\text{ s.t. }&\!\!\!\frac{1}{ER}\left(A_{0}+B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\right)E^{2}\right)\leq\epsilon\\ &K,E,R\in\mathbb{Z}^{+},\ \text{and}\ \ 1\leq K\leq N.\end{array} (16)

Combining with (15), we can see that P2 is more constrained than P1, i.e., any feasible solution of P2 is also feasible forÂ P1.

Problem P2, however, is still hard to optimize because it requires to compute various combinatorial numbers with respect to Kğ¾K. Moreover, even for a fixed value of Kğ¾K, the combinatorial term is based on the reordering of tksubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜t_{k} in (3), which is uncertain as the order of tksubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜t_{k} changes with Eğ¸E. For analytical tractability, we further approximate P2 as follows.

where we note that the objective function of P3 is equal to ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]. In the following, we solve P3 as an approximation of the original P1. Our empirical results in SectionÂ VI demonstrate that the solution obtained from solving P3 achieves near-optimal performance of the original problem P1. For ease of analysis, we incorporate Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon in the constants A0subscriptğ´0A_{0} and B0subscriptğµ0B_{0} next.

IV-B Solving the Approximate Optimization Problem P3

In this subsection, we first characterize some properties of the optimization problem P3. Then, we propose a sampling-based algorithm to learn the problem-related unknown parameters A0subscriptğ´0A_{0} and B0subscriptğµ0B_{0}, based on which the solution Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾K^{*} and Eâˆ—superscriptğ¸E^{*} (of P3) can be efficiently computed. The overall algorithm for obtaining Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾K^{*} and Eâˆ—superscriptğ¸E^{*} is given in AlgorithmÂ 2.

IV-B1 Characterizing P3

The objective function of P3 is non-convex because the determinant of its Hessian âˆ‚2ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]âˆ‚2Kâ€‹âˆ‚2ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]âˆ‚2Eâˆ’(âˆ‚2ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]âˆ‚Kâ€‹âˆ‚E)2superscript2~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶totsuperscript2ğ¾superscript2~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶totsuperscript2ğ¸superscriptsuperscript2~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶totğ¾ğ¸2\frac{\partial^{2}\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial^{2}K}\frac{\partial^{2}\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial^{2}E}-(\frac{\partial^{2}\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial K\partial E})^{2} is not always non-negative in the feasible set. However, the problem is biconvex [40].

Theorem 1.

Problem P3 is strictly biconvex.

Proof.

For any Eâ‰¥1ğ¸1E\geq 1, we have

âˆ‚2ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]âˆ‚2K=2â€‹(1âˆ’Î³)â€‹B0â€‹Nâ€‹(tpâ€‹E2+tmâ€‹E)(Nâˆ’1)â€‹K3>0.superscript2~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶totsuperscript2ğ¾21ğ›¾subscriptğµ0ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘superscriptğ¸2subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ¸ğ‘1superscriptğ¾30\frac{\partial^{2}\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial^{2}K}=\frac{2(1-\gamma)B_{0}N\left(t_{p}E^{2}+t_{m}E\right)}{(N-1)K^{3}}>0.

Similarly, for any 1â‰¤Kâ‰¤N1ğ¾ğ‘1\leq K\leq N, we have

âˆ‚2ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]âˆ‚2E=2â€‹((1âˆ’Î³)â€‹tp+Î³â€‹Kâ€‹ep)â€‹B0â€‹(1+Nâˆ’KKâ€‹(Nâˆ’1))+2â€‹A0â€‹[(1âˆ’Î³)â€‹tm+Î³â€‹Kâ€‹em]E3>0superscript2~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶totsuperscript2ğ¸absent21ğ›¾subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ›¾ğ¾subscriptğ‘’ğ‘subscriptğµ01ğ‘ğ¾ğ¾ğ‘1missing-subexpression2subscriptğ´0delimited-[]1ğ›¾subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ›¾ğ¾subscriptğ‘’ğ‘šsuperscriptğ¸30\begin{array}[]{cl}\dfrac{\partial^{2}\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial^{2}E}\!\!\!\!\!\!&=2\left(\left(1\!-\!\gamma\right)t_{p}+\gamma Ke_{p}\right)B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\right)\\ &\ \ +\dfrac{2A_{0}\left[(1\!-\!\gamma)t_{m}+\gamma Ke_{m}\right]}{E^{3}}>0\end{array}

Since the domain of Kğ¾K and Eğ¸E is convex as well, we conclude that P3 is strictly biconvex. âˆ

The biconvex property allows many efficient algorithms, such as Alternate Convex Search (ACS) approach, to a achieve a guaranteed local optima[40]. Nevertheless, by analyzing the stationary point of âˆ‚ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]âˆ‚K=0~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶totğ¾0\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial K}=0 and âˆ‚ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]âˆ‚E=0~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶totğ¸0\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial E}\!=\!0, we show that the optimal solution can be found more efficiently. This is because from âˆ‚ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]âˆ‚K=0~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶totğ¾0\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial K}\!=\!0 we have Kğ¾K in closed-form of Eğ¸E as

K=(1âˆ’Î³)â€‹B0â€‹Nâ€‹(tpâ€‹E3+tmâ€‹E2)Î³â€‹[B0â€‹(Nâˆ’2)â€‹E2+A0â€‹(Nâˆ’1)]â€‹(epâ€‹E+em).ğ¾1ğ›¾subscriptğµ0ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘superscriptğ¸3subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šsuperscriptğ¸2ğ›¾delimited-[]subscriptğµ0ğ‘2superscriptğ¸2subscriptğ´0ğ‘1subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ¸subscriptğ‘’ğ‘šmissing-subexpression\begin{array}[]{cl}K=\sqrt{\frac{(1-\gamma)B_{0}N\left(t_{p}E^{3}+t_{m}E^{2}\right)}{\gamma\left[B_{0}(N-2)E^{2}+A_{0}(N-1)\right](e_{p}E+{e_{m}})}}.\end{array} (21)

By letting âˆ‚ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]âˆ‚E=0~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶totğ¸0\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial E}=0, we derive the cubic equation of Eğ¸E as

2â€‹(1âˆ’Î³)â€‹tp+Î³â€‹Kâ€‹ep2â€‹(1âˆ’Î³)â€‹tm+Î³â€‹Kâ€‹emâ€‹E3+E2âˆ’A0B0â€‹(1+Nâˆ’KKâ€‹(Nâˆ’1))=0,21ğ›¾subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ›¾ğ¾subscriptğ‘’ğ‘21ğ›¾subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ›¾ğ¾subscriptğ‘’ğ‘šsuperscriptğ¸3superscriptğ¸2subscriptğ´0subscriptğµ01ğ‘ğ¾ğ¾ğ‘10missing-subexpression\begin{array}[]{cl}\frac{2\left(1-\gamma\right)t_{p}+\gamma Ke_{p}}{2\left(1-\gamma\right)t_{m}+\gamma Ke_{m}}E^{3}+E^{2}-{\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\right)}}\!=\!0,\end{array} (22)

which can be analytically solved in closed-form of Kğ¾K via Cardano formula [41]. Therefore, for any fixed value of Kğ¾K, due to biconvexity (TheoremÂ 1), we have a unique real solution of Eğ¸E from (22) in closed form. Then, with ACS method we iteratively calculate (21) and (22) which keeps decreasing the objective function until we achieve the converged Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾âˆ—K^{\ast} and Eâˆ—superscriptğ¸âˆ—E^{\ast}. This optimization process corresponds to LinesÂ 2â€“2 of AlgorithmÂ 2, where LinesÂ 2 and 2 ensure that the solution is taken within the feasibility region, and LineÂ 2 rounds the continuous values of Kğ¾K and Eğ¸E to integer values.

IV-B2 Estimation of Parameters A0B0subscriptğ´0subscriptğµ0\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}}

In the following, we propose a sampling-based algorithm to estimate A0B0subscriptğ´0subscriptğµ0\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}}, and show that the overhead for estimation is marginal.

V Solution Property for Cost Minimization

We theoretically analyze the solution properties for different metric preferences, which not only provide insightful design principles but also give alternative ways of solving P3 to more efficiently. Our empirical results show that these properties derived for P3 are still valid for the original P1. In the following, we discuss the properties for Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0 and Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1, respectively. For ease of presentation, we consider continuous Kğ¾K, Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾K^{*}, Eğ¸E, and Eâˆ—superscriptğ¸E^{*} (i.e., before rounding) in this section.

V-A Properties for Minimizing ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] when Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0

When the design goal is to minimize learning time (Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0), the objective of P3 can be rewritten as

minE,Kâ¡(tmE+tp)â‹…(A0+B0â€‹(1+Nâˆ’KKâ€‹(Nâˆ’1))â€‹E2)â‹…subscriptğ¸ğ¾subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ¸subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ´0subscriptğµ01ğ‘ğ¾ğ¾ğ‘1superscriptğ¸2\begin{array}[]{c}\min_{E,K}\ \left(\frac{t_{m}}{E}+t_{p}\right)\cdot\left(A_{0}+B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\right)E^{2}\right)\end{array} (27)

We present the following insightful results to characterize the properties of Eâˆ—superscriptğ¸E^{*} and Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾K^{*}.

Theorem 2.

When Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0, ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] is a strictly decreasing function in Kğ¾K for any given Eğ¸E, hence Kâˆ—=Nsuperscriptğ¾ğ‘K^{*}=N.

Proof.

The proof is straightforward, as we are able to show for any Eğ¸E, âˆ‚ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]âˆ‚K<0~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶totğ¾0\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial K}<0. Since Kâ‰¤Nğ¾ğ‘K\leq N, we have Kâˆ—=Nsuperscriptğ¾ğ‘K^{*}=N. The same result can also be obtained by letting Î³â†’0â†’ğ›¾0\gamma\rightarrow 0 in (21). âˆ

Remark: In practical FL applications, Nğ‘N can be very large, and thus, full participation (K=Nğ¾ğ‘K\!=\!N) is usually intractable. However, since the objective function in (27) is strictly convex and decreasing with Kğ¾K, as Kğ¾K increases, the marginal learning time decrease becomes smaller as well. Therefore, when Nğ‘N is very large, sampling a small portion of devices can achieve a relative good learning time. Our later real-data experiment shows that sampling K=20ğ¾20K\!=\!20 out of N=100ğ‘100N\!=\!100 devices achieves a similar performance as sampling all devices.

Based on the above finding, it is important to analyze the property of Eğ¸E when Kğ¾K is chosen sub-optimally. In line with this, we present the following two corollaries.

Corollary 1.

When Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0, for any fixed value of Kğ¾K, as Eğ¸E increases, ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] first decreases and then increases.

Proof.

Taking the first order derivative of ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] over Eğ¸E,

âˆ‚ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]âˆ‚E=B0â€‹(2â€‹tpâ€‹E+tm)â€‹(1+Nâˆ’KKâ€‹(Nâˆ’1))âˆ’tmâ€‹A0E2.~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶totğ¸subscriptğµ02subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ¸subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘š1ğ‘ğ¾ğ¾ğ‘1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šsubscriptğ´0superscriptğ¸2\begin{array}[]{c}\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial E}=B_{0}\left(2t_{p}E+t_{m}\right)\left(1+\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\right)-\frac{t_{m}A_{0}}{E^{2}}.\end{array} (28)

Since 0â‰¤Nâˆ’KKâ€‹(Nâˆ’1)â‰¤10ğ‘ğ¾ğ¾ğ‘110\leq\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\leq 1 for any feasible Kğ¾K, (28) is negative when Eğ¸E is small and positive when Eğ¸E is large. âˆ

Corollary 1 shows that for any given Kğ¾K, Eğ¸E should not be set too small nor too large for saving learning time.

Corollary 2.

When Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0, for any fixed value of Kğ¾K, Eâˆ—superscriptğ¸E^{*} increases as tmtpsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘\frac{t_{m}}{t_{p}} increases.

We omit the proof of CorollaryÂ 2 due to page limitation. Intuitively, CorollaryÂ 2 says that for any given Kğ¾K, when tmsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘št_{m} increases or tpsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘t_{p} decreases, the optimal strategy to reduce learning time is to perform more steps of iterations (i.e., increase Eğ¸E) before aggregation, which matches the empirical observations for communication efficiency in [2, 19, 20].

V-B Properties for Minimizing ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] when Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1

When the design goal is to minimize energy consumption (Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1), the objective of P3 can be rewritten as

minE,Kâ¡(emâ€‹KE+epâ€‹K)â€‹(A0+B0â€‹(1+Nâˆ’KKâ€‹(Nâˆ’1))â€‹E2).subscriptğ¸ğ¾subscriptğ‘’ğ‘šğ¾ğ¸subscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ¾subscriptğ´0subscriptğµ01ğ‘ğ¾ğ¾ğ‘1superscriptğ¸2\begin{array}[]{c}\min_{E,K}\left(\frac{e_{m}K}{E}\!+\!e_{p}K\right)\left(A_{0}\!+\!B_{0}\left(1\!+\frac{N-K}{K(N\!-\!1)}\right)\!E^{2}\right).\end{array} (29)

Besides the different metrics of emsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘še_{m} and epsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘e_{p}, the key difference between (27) and (29) is the multiplication of Kğ¾K. Therefore, the main difference between Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1 and Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0 is in the properties related to Kğ¾K, whereas the properties related to Eğ¸E remain similar, which we show in the following.

Theorem 3.

When Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1, ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] is a strictly increasing function in Kğ¾K for any given Eğ¸E, hence Kâˆ—=1superscriptğ¾1K^{*}=1.

Proof.

It is easy to show that âˆ‚ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]âˆ‚K>0~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶totğ¾0\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial K}>0 for any given Eğ¸E. Since Kâ‰¥1ğ¾1K\geq 1, we have Kâˆ—=1superscriptğ¾1K^{*}=1. This conclusion can also be obtained when we let Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1 in (21) since 1â‰¤Kâ‰¤N1ğ¾ğ‘1\leq K\leq N. âˆ

Remark: Theorem 3 shows that sampling fewer devices can reduce the total energy consumption, whereas according to TheoremÂ 2, this results in a longer learning time. While this may seem contradictory at the first glance, we note that this result is correct because the total energy is the sum energy consumption of all selected clients. Although it takes longer time to reach the desired precision Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon with a smaller Kğ¾K, there are also less number of clients participating in each round, so the total energy consumption can be smaller.

Corollary 3.

When Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma\!=\!1, for any fixed value of Kğ¾K, as Eğ¸E increases, ğ”¼~â€‹[Ctot]~ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ¶tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] first decreases and then increases.

Corollary 4.

When Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma\!=\!1, for any fixed value of Kğ¾K, Eâˆ—superscriptğ¸E^{*} increases as emepsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘\frac{e_{m}}{e_{p}} increases.

The proofs and intuitions for Corollaries 3 and 4 are similar to Corollaries 1 and 2, which we omit due to page limitation.

V-C Trade-off Between Learning Time and Energy Consumption

In the above analysis, we derived a trade-off design principle for Kğ¾K, with a larger Kğ¾K favoring learning time reduction, while a smaller Kğ¾K favoring energy saving. For a given Î³ğ›¾\gamma, the optimal Kğ¾K achieves the right balance between reducing learning time and energy consumption.

Theorem 4.

Assume that the power used for computation and communication are the same (i.e., emtm=eptpsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘\frac{e_{m}}{t_{m}}=\frac{e_{p}}{t_{p}}), then Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾K^{*} and Eâˆ—superscriptğ¸E^{*} both decrease as Î³ğ›¾\gamma increases.

We omit the full proof due to page limitation. Intuitively, emtm=eptpsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘\frac{e_{m}}{t_{m}}=\frac{e_{p}}{t_{p}} yields tptm=epemsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘subscriptğ‘’ğ‘š\frac{t_{p}}{t_{m}}=\frac{e_{p}}{e_{m}}. Hence, the quantities tpâ€‹E+tmepâ€‹E+emsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ¸subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ¸subscriptğ‘’ğ‘š\frac{t_{p}E+t_{m}}{e_{p}E+e_{m}} and 2â€‹(1âˆ’Î³)â€‹tp+Î³â€‹Kâ€‹ep2â€‹(1âˆ’Î³)â€‹tm+Î³â€‹Kâ€‹em21ğ›¾subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘ğ›¾ğ¾subscriptğ‘’ğ‘21ğ›¾subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ›¾ğ¾subscriptğ‘’ğ‘š\frac{2\left(1-\gamma\right)t_{p}+\gamma Ke_{p}}{2\left(1-\gamma\right)t_{m}+\gamma Ke_{m}} in (21) and (22), respectively, remain unchanged regardless of the values of Kğ¾K, Eğ¸E, and Î³ğ›¾\gamma. By some algebraic manipulations, we can see from (21) and (22) that when Î³ğ›¾\gamma increases or Eğ¸E decreases, the value of Kğ¾K according to (21) decreases; when Kğ¾K decreases, the solution of Eğ¸E from (22) also decreases (note that this solution remains unchanged regardless of Î³ğ›¾\gamma). Therefore, whenever Î³ğ›¾\gamma increases, Kğ¾K will decrease, then Eğ¸E will decrease, and so on, until converging to a new (Kâˆ—,Eâˆ—)superscriptğ¾superscriptğ¸(K^{*},E^{*}) that is smaller than before, and vice versa.

VI Experimental Evaluation

In this section, we evaluate the performance of our proposed cost-effective FL algorithm and verify our derived solution properties. We start by presenting the evaluation setup, and then show the experimental results.

VI-A Experimental Setup

VI-A1 Platforms

We conducted experiments both on a networked hardware prototype system and in a simulated environment. Our prototype system, as illustrated in Fig.Â 2, consists of N=20ğ‘20N=20 Raspberry Pis (version 4) serving as devices and a laptop computer serving as the central server. All devices are interconnected via an enterprise Wi-Fi router, and we developed a TCP-based socket interface for the peer-to-peer connection. In the simulation system, we simulated N=100ğ‘100N=100 virtual devices and a virtual central server.

VI-A2 Datasets and Models

We evaluate our results both on a real dataset and a synthetic dataset. For the real dataset, we adopted the widely used MNIST dataset [42], which contains square 28Ã—28=784282878428\times 28=784 pixel gray-scale images of 70,0007000070,000 handwritten digits (60,0006000060,000 for training and 10,0001000010,000 for testing). For the synthetic dataset, we follow a similar setup to that in [10], which generates 606060-dimensional random vectors as input data. The synthetic data is denoted by Sâ€‹yâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹hâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹iâ€‹câ€‹(Î±,Î²)ğ‘†ğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘¡â„ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘ğ›¼ğ›½Synthetic\ (\alpha,\beta) with Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta representing the statistical heterogeneity (i.e., how non-i.i.d. the data are). We adopt both the convex multinomial logistic regression model [11] and the non-convex deep convolutional neural network (CNN) model with LeNet-5 architecture [42].

VI-A3 Implementation

Based on the above, we consider the following three experimental setups.

Setup 1: We conduct the first experiment on the prototype system using logistic regression and MNIST dataset, where we divide 6,00060006,000 data samples (randomly sampled one-tenth of the total samples) among N=20ğ‘20N\!=\!20 Raspberry Pis in a non-i.i.d. fashion with each device containing a balanced number of 300300300 samples of only 222 digits labels.

Setup 2: We conduct the second experiment in the simulated system using CNN and MNIST dataset, where we divide all 60,0006000060,000 data samples among N=100ğ‘100N\!=\!100 devices in the same non-i.i.d fashion as in Setup 1, but the amount of data in each device follows the inherent unbalanced digit label distribution of MNIST, where the number of samples in each device has a mean of 600600600 and standard deviation of 20.120.120.1.

Setup 3: We conduct the third experiment in the simulated system using logistic regression and Sâ€‹yâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹hâ€‹eâ€‹tâ€‹iâ€‹câ€‹(1,1)ğ‘†ğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘¡â„ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘11Synthetic\ (1,1) dataset for statistical heterogeneity, where we generate 24,5172451724,517 data samples and distribute them among N=100ğ‘100N\!=\!100 devices in an unbalanced power law distribution, where the number of samples in each device has a mean of 245245245 and standard deviation of 362362362.

VI-A4 Training Parameters

For all experiments, we initialize our model with ğ°0=ğŸsubscriptğ°00\mathbf{w}_{0}=\mathbf{0} and SGD batch size b=64ğ‘64b=64. In each round, we uniformly sample Kğ¾K devices at random, which run Eğ¸E steps of SGD in parallel. For the prototype system, we use an initial learning rate Î·0=0.01subscriptğœ‚00.01\eta_{0}=0.01 with a fixed decay rate of 0.9960.9960.996. For the simulation system, we use decay rate Î·01+rsubscriptğœ‚01ğ‘Ÿ\frac{{\eta}_{0}}{1+r}, where Î·0=0.1subscriptğœ‚00.1\eta_{0}=0.1 and rğ‘Ÿr is communication round index. We evaluate the aggregated model in each round on the global loss function. Each result is averaged over 50 experiments.

VI-A5 Heterogeneous System Parameters

The prototype system allows us to capture real system heterogeneity in terms of communication and computation time, which we measured the average tp=3.1Ã—10âˆ’3subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘3.1superscript103t_{p}\!=\!3.1\times 10^{-3}s with standard deviation 2.3Ã—10âˆ’42.3superscript1042.3\times 10^{-4}s and tm=0.34subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘š0.34t_{m}\!=\!0.34s with standard deviation 1.56Ã—10âˆ’31.56superscript1031.56\times 10^{-3}s. We do not capture the energy cost in the prototype system because it is difficult to measure. For the simulation system, we generate the learning time and energy consumption for each client kğ‘˜k using a normal distribution with mean tp=0.1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘0.1t_{p}\!=\!0.1s, tm=2subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘š2t_{m}\!=\!2s, ep=10âˆ’3subscriptğ‘’ğ‘superscript103e_{p}\!=\!10^{-3}J, and em=2Ã—10âˆ’2subscriptğ‘’ğ‘š2superscript102e_{m}\!=\!2\times 10^{-2}J and standard deviation of the mean divided by 333. According to the definition of Î³ğ›¾\gamma, we unify the time and energy costs such that one second is equivalent to 1âˆ’Î³1ğ›¾1-\gamma dollarsÂ ($) and one Joule is equivalent to Î³ğ›¾\gamma dollarsÂ ($).

VI-B3 Impact of Weight Î³ğ›¾\gamma

Figs.Â 5(a) â€“ 5(c) show that when the weight Î³ğ›¾\gamma increases from 00 to 111 (corresponding to the design preference varying from reducing learning time to saving energy consumption), both the optimal and our proposed solutions of Kğ¾K decrease from N=100ğ‘100N\!=\!100 to 111. By iterating through the entire range of Î³ğ›¾\gamma, Fig.Â 5(e) depicts the trade-off curve between the learning time cost and energy consumption cost, where our algorithm is capable of balancing the two metrics as well as approaching the optimal.

VI-B4 Property Validation

We highlight that our derived theoretical properties of Kğ¾K and Eğ¸E in SectionÂ V can be validated empirically, which we summarize as follows.101010The property of CorollariesÂ 2 and 4 can also be validated, which we do not show in this paper due to page limitation.

  • â€¢

    Figs.Â 3(c), 4(c), and 5(a) demonstrate that for any fixed value Eğ¸E, the learning time cost (Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma\!=\!0) strictly decreases in Kğ¾K, which confirms the claim in Theorem 2 that sampling more clients can speed up learning. Moreover, we observe in these figures that sampling fewer clients (15 out of 20 for Setup 1 and 20 out of 100 for Setups 2 and 3) does not affect the learning time much, which confirms our Remark. Nevertheless, Fig.Â 5(c) shows that for any fixed value Eğ¸E, the energy consumption cost (Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma\!=\!1) strictly increases in Kğ¾K, which confirms Theorem 3 that sampling fewer clients reduces energy consumption.

  • â€¢

    Figs.Â 3(c), 4(c), 5(a)â€“5(c) demonstrate that, for any fixed value of Kğ¾K, the corresponding cost first decreases and then increases as Eğ¸E increases, which confirms CorollariesÂ 1 and 3 as well as the biconvex property in TheoremÂ 1. Since emtm=eptp=10âˆ’2subscriptğ‘’ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘superscript102\frac{e_{m}}{t_{m}}=\frac{e_{p}}{t_{p}}=10^{-2} in our simulation system, we observe from Figs.Â 3(c), 4(c), and 5(a) that both Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾âˆ—K^{\ast} and Eâˆ—superscriptğ¸âˆ—E^{\ast} decrease as Î³ğ›¾\gamma increases, which confirms TheoremÂ 4.

VII Conclusion

In this work, we have studied the cost-effective design for FL. We analyzed how to optimally choose the number of participating clients (Kğ¾K) and the number of local iterations (Eğ¸E), which are two essential control variables in FL, to minimize the total cost while ensuring convergence. We proposed a sampling-based control algorithm which efficiently solves the optimization problem with marginal overhead. We also derived insightful solution properties which helps identify the design principles for different optimization goals, e.g., reducing learning time or saving energy. Extensive experimentation results validated our theoretical analysis and demonstrated the effectiveness and efficiency of our control algorithm. Our optimization design is orthogonal to most works on resource allocation for FL systems, and can be used together with those techniques to further reduce the cost.
